results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 7]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snapshot of a family holiday in Japan, possibly in Nikko.

Nikko is a small city in Japan’s Tochigi Prefecture, in the mountains north of Tokyo.

The film opens with a scene of tourists boarding a Nikko Tour tourist bus on their way to a sightseeing trip to the mountains.

A stop-over sees Maurie’s son slipping and sliding along a snow-covered path and Maurie performing an impromptu ice-skating sequence - without the ice skates.

We see monkeys, probably Japanese Macaques, along the side of the road as cars drive past.

Looking out from the bus window we see a landscape of snow-capped mountains and winding roads at altitude.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 6]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snapshot of a family holiday in Thailand.

Some sections of this film have exposure and focus issues, as well as the occasional hair in the gate.

The film opens with scenes shot from a tourist boat trip through the Khlongs (canals) of what could be the Chao Phraya River in the Thonburi area of Bangkok Thailand. Along the way of the canals and river, we see a convoy of traditional river boats, canoes and rice barges.

There are scenes from what appears to be a “cultural show” performed for tourists. We see a procession of people wearing traditional Thai dress accompanied by decorated elephants. There is a martial arts performance including Kickboxing, Muay Thai and Krabi-Krabong, a weapon based martial art demonstrated using sticks. There are scenes of a cock fight, musicians and men and women performing Lao Kra Top or bamboo dancing.

The film also shows tourists riding elephants.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 5]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snapshot of a family holiday in Thailand and Japan.

The film opens with scenes shot from a tourist boat trip through the Khlongs (canals) of what could be the Chao Phraya River in the Thonburi area of Bangkok Thailand. Along the way of the canals and river, we see tropical water plants, traditional canoes and wooden stilt houses. Washing is strung from a clothes line across the fronts of houses and there are people bathing and cleaning their pots and pans with water scooped from the river.

A stop-over includes scenes of Maurie Fields and Vally Jellay participating in a dance activity along with fellow tourists and children wearing traditional dress.

The family then travel to Japan, taking a train trip to Nikko. Nikko is a small city in Japan’s Tochigi Prefecture, in the mountains north of Tokyo.

Views from the train window include snow-capped mountains, buildings and houses in the snow. We see a Nikko Tobu sign on a railway platform and a welcome sign for the Nikko Kanaya Hotel upon arrival.

People throw snow balls and we see Nikko Tour tourist buses parked along the street beside cars and buildings that reflect the culture and the era.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 4]
results.brief_description:
This film is an excerpt from a family trip to Los Angeles and Universal Studios in Hollywood. Some parts of this film have an occasional hair in the gate.

The opening scenes of the film appear to depict a studio tour of the backlot of Universal Studios. We see a steam train departing from a platform with the signage “Ridgeway Elevation 3820”. There is a wild west show at the Silver Slippery Saloon, and shots of what could be Falls Lake with what appears to be the house from ‘Psycho’ in the background. We see Frankenstein’s monster feign strangling a suspecting Val Jellay.

Out in the streets of Los Angeles and Hollywood in particular, the film shows the Capitol Records tower as well as Hollywood Palace signage, buildings, and the Crown Derby Coffee Shop sign.

Street scenes, possibly on the Universal Studios backlot, reveal gothic architecture as well as buildings with Doric and Corinthian columns.

We see Maurie Fields and a friend sitting outdoors beside a tennis court which could possibly be a part of a hotel or resort.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlight
00:02:27:00 buildings along what could possibly be Universal Studios backlot

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 3]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snapshot of a family holiday in the Philippines, showing Manila street scenes and a sightseeing trip to the outskirts.

The film opens with scenes of a bamboo hut with a thatched roof set at the base of a hill. The hut appears to be a shop set up for tourists. It sells batik style clothing, and there is a sign post reading “Fiesta Batik Welcome”. There is a rudimentary brick church alongside the shop. We see Val Jellay walk down a dirt path past the church to join the other tourists on the bus.

Back at the hotel or resort, the film shows a swimming pool, umbrellas, sun lounges and a lifesaving ring with the inscription “Regency Manila”.

There is a road trip through the congested streets of Manila revealing colourful Jeepnies, Kalesas (horse drawn carriages), Volkswagen Beetles, a Kombi Van, taxis and local buses. We see street signs reading “Tokyo”, “Joy Mart” and “Gamma import-export” with the phone number.

Maurie takes us across the river and we see what could be the art deco Quezon Bridge which spans the Pasig River in Manila.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:14:00 bamboo hut/shop at base of hill
00:00:17:00 Fiesta Batik sign
00:00:21:00 bamboo hut/shop with Val in kaftan
00:00:32:00 brick church
00:01:28:00 streets lined with Volkswagen Beetles

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 2]
results.brief_description:
This film is a snapshot of a family holiday in Bangkok, Thailand.

Some of the footage is underexposed with a hair in the gate in some sections.

The film opens with scenes shot from a tourist boat trip through the Khlongs (canals) of what could be the Chao Phraya River in the Thonburi area of Bangkok Thailand. Along the way of the canals and river, we see tropical water plants lining either side of the narrow khlongs, traditional and motorised canoes, and square, fishing bag-nets. There are scenes of crumbling wooden stilt houses, river boats, colourful river ferries, longtail boats and Buddhist shrines. A stop-over includes scenes of tourists (possible family) riding a water buffalo.

Back on board there is beer and food served amidst an atmosphere of jolly tourist bonhomie. The beautiful Val Jellay drinks her beer in the “magic hour”.

Originally shot on Super 8mm film.

Selected highlight:
00:02:00:00 Val Jellay on board the boat

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 16]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a family holiday in Cairns and Kuranda in North Queensland.

The film opens with scenes shot from the bow of an Attack Class patrol boat, the HMAS Barbette, which was re-located from Sydney to the port at Cairns in 1971.

As the patrol boat travels on the ocean, we see the vessels’s name plate reading “Barbette” and various equipment on the deck including armament. We see naval vessels sailing behind and flanking the Barbette, and Maurie’s son on board.

The family join a sightseeing tour on board the Kuranda Scenic Railway. As the train climbs through the Macalister Ranges we see the surrounding countryside including farms, ravines, the Barron Falls, the Barron River and the Barron Falls Weir. The film also shows the front carriages of the train snaking their way along the railway track.

Originally made on 8mm film

Selected highlight
00:01:55:00 Carriages of the Kuranda Scenic Railway

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 15]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a family holiday in and around Cairns in North Queensland.

A label on the film reel notes Cairns and Hart Creek.

The film opens with bucolic scenes of children swimming and launching themselves from a rope tree-swing into a creek. From the surrounding and background scenery, the creek appears to be in a tropical location possibly Far North Queensland.

The family then travel to an idyllic looking beach fringed with coconut palms, calm water, and an island in the background. Hurling rocks, Maurie and his son attempt to dislodge a coconut from its lofty mooring to no avail. We see Val attempt to scale the heights by using the foot and hand holds carved into the trunk of the coconut palm. She too is equally unsuccessful in bringing down a coconut. She appears to be happy enough just to hug the tree instead.

A visit to an animal enclosure shows a crocodile, peacocks, and turtles. Maurie and Val enjoy a tropical lunch stop complete with a pleasingly decorated fresh pineapple for table-side garnish.

The film closes as we see Maurie in profile lighting a cigarette framed by the tropical hills.

Originally made on 8mm film

Selected highlights list
00:01:02:00 Maurie attempts to dislodge a coconut from a palm tree

00:01:25:00 Val climbs a coconut palm

00:01:48:00 Tropical beach scene

00:02:58:00 Maurie looks towards the camera

00:03:17:00 Maurie lights a cigarette framed by tropical hills

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 14]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a family holiday to Kuranda in North Queensland and a trip on a P&O liner in Sydney Harbour.

Some sections of this film appear over-exposed.

The film opens with lovely views of what appears to be the Barron Falls in Barron Gorge National Park, North Queensland. The family can be seen admiring the view of the waterfalls from a train carriage on board the Kuranda Scenic Railway. We see a motel/apartment beachfront complex located in possibly New South Wales or Queensland. The film shows the lovely surf beach and buildings along the foreshore.

In Sydney, the family board The Chitral, a P&O passenger ship. They walk up the gang plank and wave farewell to the camera. There are great scenes of Sydney Harbour as they sail under the harbour bridge and past the Sydney Opera House which seems to be under construction with cranes in the foreground. We also see ships, yachts, ferries, and a police speed boat. The giant smiling mouth and towers marking the entrance to Luna Park can be seen in the background.

Originally made on 8mm film

Selected highlights list
00:00:03:00 Barron Falls

00:00:20:00 Maurie sightseeing at the Falls

00:02:28:00 Val and view of Sydney Harbour from passenger liner

00:02:47:00 Maurie on board passenger ship

00:03:02:00 Sailing under Sydney Harbour Bridge with Luna Park in the background

00:03:22:00 Val blowing a kiss to camera with Sydney Harbour Bridge in the background

00:03:30:00 Sailing past the Sydney Opera House with cranes in the foreground

00:02:28:00 Val and view of Sydney Harbour from passenger liner

00:02:47:00 Maurie on board passenger ship

00:03:02:00 Sailing under Sydney Harbour Bridge with Luna Park in the background

00:03:22:00 Val blowing a kiss to camera with Sydney Harbour Bridge in the background

00:03:30:00 Sailing past the Sydney Opera House with cranes in the foreground

details.label: Subject categories
display_values: Climate, Environment, Natural Resources & Disasters → National parks and reserves - Australia

results.title: [Maurie Fields and Val Jellay Home Movies: Reel 13]
results.brief_description:
This film shows a family road trip to Deniliquen in New South Wales. Along the way we see various stopovers including a visit to the Bellbird Hotel and a pig farm.

The film opens with Maurie and possibly his son standing in front of a sign to the Bellbird Hotel in Bellbird Creek, Victoria. This is particularly relevant as Maurie played the town nastie John Quinney in the ABCTV series ‘Bellbird’ which ran from 1967 to 1977. We see Maurie enter through a glass door bearing the sign Bellbird Hotel Bar.

The next location shows Maurie standing on a roof- top clearing leaves. There are fruit trees and a Hills Hoist in the garden.

Children enjoy playing in a swimming pool which appears to be a part of a motel complex. There is a visit to a pig farm showing scenes of the family pig feeding, pig patting and pigs wallowing in mud.

The film shows a tinny boat trip down a river which could be the Edward River in Deniliquen. River gums line the banks of the river and a water skier is towed along by a speed boat.

Originally made on 8mm film

Selected highlights list:
00:00:02:00 Maurie and son stand in front of Bellbird Hotel sign

00:00:12:00 Entrance door to Bellbird Hotel Bar

00:01:14:00 A farmer, Maurie and son at the pig farm
